summary: The Project Manager introduced the project to the group and gave a timeline for the project. The group trained themselves to use the meeting room tools by drawing on the whiteboard. The Project Manager presented the project budget and the projected price point and profit goals. The group discussed several of their initial ideas for the features of the product. They discussed making the remote able to control multiple devices, protection from water or from dropping the remote, and a locator function. The Project Manager then instructed the User Interface Designer to research users' requirements, and instructed the Industrial and User Interface Designers to research the functions and usability features that were discussed in the meeting.
actions: The Industrial Designer will do research on the whistle tracking locator function and other functional components. The User Interface Designer will research the necessary amount of buttons and the lighted interface that were discussed during the meeting and other usability features. The Marketing Expert will research users' requirements for a remote control device.
decisions: The group would like the remote to control multiple devices and have optional water and other damage protection. The group will research the possibility of integrating a locator function into the design.

whiteboard.ocr_transcript: There is no text written on this image.
whiteboard.ocr_description:
The image is a simple, hand-drawn sketch featuring what appears to be a variety of whimsical and abstract elements:

1. In the foreground, there's a creature with the body of what looks like a seal or a similar animal, but with a cat-like face, featuring a nose, whiskers, and a smiling face.

2. In the background, there is another figure that seems to have a simplistic, straight-lined design. It has a rectangular body and a long, rectangular head, and it might represent an anthropomorphized animal or an abstract figure, possibly resembling a giraffe or a horse with simplistic and stylized features.

The overall drawing is playful and abstract, combining animal features in a fun, imaginative way.

1: Agenda

Opening
Project Manager = secretary (minutes)
3 presentations
New project requirements
Decision on remote control functions
Closing (we have 40 minutes!)
2: New project requirements

Teletext becomes outdated, since the popularity of the Internet. 
The remote control should only be used for the television, otherwise the project becomes more complex, which endangers the time-to-market. 
Our corporate image should stay recognizable in our products. Our corporate color and slogan must be implemented in the new design.
3:
Now: lunch break
Then 30 minutes of individual work
PM: puts minutes in Project Documents folder
Individual actions
ID: the components concept 
UID: the user interface concept 
ME: trend watching 
Specific instructions will be sent to you by your personal coach.

1: Method

Standard chip for remote control
Case study for wheel sensor
Case study for standard BP
2: Findings

Standard TA11835 element for RC coding
Use of off the shelf PCP buttons
Use of standard wheel sensor (price)

1: Method

I select materials and designs that fit comfortably and non-intrusively in a remote control
We want a design that is as simple as possible, but not simpler. It must be robust.
2: Findings
This is a simple remote similar to what we want.
3:
We must design something similar to these two, but without the extra buttons. We replace the channel up down button with a wheel. The wheel can be pushed down for channel recall(?)
A plastic opening for the channel numbers is unnecessary and cubersome. It is also prone to breakage. It suffices for digits to  be well separated from the rest of the buttons.

1: Method
The evaluation criteria is made according to the users requirements and the market trends we talked about on the previous meetings.
2: Evaluation

Fancy look-and-feel
Technological innovative
Easy-to-use
Fashion
Easy to find in a room
Robust

1: Method

In our usability lab we observed the remote control use among 100 subjects 
They also filled in a questionnaire.
2: Findings

75% of users find most remote controls ugly 
80% of users would spend more money when a remote control would look fancy
 80% of users would spend more money when a remote control would look fancy 
80% of users would spend more money when a remote control would look fancy
3:
The biggest frustrations users expressed:
Remote controls are often lost somewhere in the room (50%) 
It takes too much time to learn how to use a new remote control (34%) 
Remote controls are bad for RSI (26%)
4:
Questions asked:
Would you prefer an LCD screen on a multifunction remote control? 
 Would you pay more for speech recognition in a remote control?
6:
Lightening in the dark
Not too many buttons
A way to find it easily

0: Presented by: Karin de Groot, Marketing Expert
1: Findings

Criteria:
Original
Trendy
A fancy feel and look
Technologically innovative
Easy to use
Soft and curved materials
A fruit design
2:
Evaluation
Criteria rating with seven-point scale


		The remote control is according criteria X.

0: Presented by: Karin de Groot, Market Expert
1: Method

Working method: internet research

100 subjects filled in a questionnaire
2: Findings

Users dislike the look-and-feel of current remote controls

75% of users find most remote controls ugly  
80% of users would spend more money when a remote control would look fancy 
50% of users say they only use 10% of the buttons
Current remote controls do not match well the operating behavior of the user
3:
Remote controls are often lost somewhere in the room (50%) 

It takes too much time to learn how to use a new remote control (34%) 

Remote controls are bad for RSI (26%)
4:
Would you prefer an LCD screen on a multifunction remote control? 

Age group 15-45 YES

Age group 45- 65 NO
5:
Would you pay more for speech recognition in a remote control? 

Age group 15-35 YES

Age group 35- 65 NO
6:
Original
Trendy
User friendly
	- Most important are the functions:
Channel- and volume selection

 Less important are the functions audio- and screen settings (mono/stereo, brightness, color etc.)

0:
Presented by: Karin de Groot,
Marketing Expert
1: Findings

a fancy look-and-feel, instead of the current functional look-and-feel

2.	a remote control should be technological innovative

3.	the remote control should be easy-to-use
2: Market trends

This year, fruit will be the most important theme for clothes, shoes, and furniture

In contrast to last year, the feel of material is expected to be soft and curved
3:
“We put the fashion into electronics”, so

1.	Let’s use a fruit design for a fancy look

Let’s use some soft and curved materials for a fancy feel

Maybe the remote control can spread a fruity smell, to be innovative

Don’t forget: the remote control should be easy-to-use

1: Trends

Recent investigation of the remote control market shows the following:
	- The most important aspect for remote controls happens to be a fancy look-and-feel, instead of the current functional look-and-feel. This aspect is twice as important as the second aspect. 
	- The second most important aspect is that a remote control should be technological innovative. In turn, this aspect is twice as important as the next aspect. 
	- The third most important aspect is that the remote control should be easy-to-use.
2: Trends

Fashion watchers in Paris and Milan have detected the following trends: 
	- This year, fruit & vegetables will be the most important theme for cloths, shoes, and furniture.
	- Also in contrast to last year, the feel of material is expected to be spongy.
3:
Choose a fruit or a vegetable to design the remote control?
What material can we use to make the remote control spongy?

doc.content:
A new television remote control

Industrial design

Jona Rovers

Working design: how does the apparatus work to fulfill its functions 

Buttons on the remote make contact with something like a chip, sends signal to TV. Settings on TV are changed.



Remote is supposed to set the tv to ‘active’



Pressing various buttons triggers various actions



ACTIONS

Primary

Turn TV on/off (from standby-state

‘zapping’ – changing/selecting channels, ‘next/previous’ and ‘channelnumber’ selection

Changing volume

Changing color/brightness/contrast etc.



Secondary

What are the wishes of ‘the consumers’??



Options

 ‘Teletext’ – English??

Automatic channelsearch

Etc.

The remote control is original.

FUNCTION DESIGN PHASE

What needs and desires are to be fulfilled?





The new remote control has to be:



User friendly

Trendy (“We put the fashion in electronics!”)

Original
